Stats reflect time with the Penguins only.
‡Denotes player was traded mid-season. Stats reflect time with the Penguins only. ==Awards and records== * [[Mario Lemieux]] became the first person to score 70 assists in a season for the Penguins. He did so in a 7–3 win over [[Detroit Red Wings|Detroit]] on February 21st. * [[Mario Lemieux]] became the first person to score 80 assists and also 120 points in a season for the Penguins. He did so with the same assist in a 5–1 win over [[Hartford Whalers|Hartford]] on March 1st. * [[Mario Lemieux]] became the first person to score 130 points in a season for the Penguins. He did so in a 7–3 win over [[New Jersey Devils|New Jersey]] on March 19th. * [[Mario Lemieux]] became the first person to score 90 assists in a season for the Penguins. He did so in a 3–8 loss to with [[Edmonton Oilers|Edmonton]] on March 26th. * [[Mario Lemieux]] became the first person to score 140 points in a season for the Penguins. He did so in a 5–4 win over [[New York Rangers|New York]] on April 6th. * [[Mario Lemieux]] established a new franchise record for assists (94) and points (141) in a season. He topped the previous highs of 111 points ([[Pierre Larouche]], 1976) and 67 assists ([[Syl Apps, Jr.]] 1976 and [[Randy Carlyle]] 1981). ==Transactions== The Penguins were involved in the following transactions during the 1985–86 season: ===Trades=== {| cellspacing=0 class="wikitable" style="border:1px solid #999999; width:80%;" |- bgcolor="eeeeee" | style="width:22%;" | September 10, 1985 | style="width:39%;" valign="top"| To [[1985–86 Edmonton Oilers season|Edmonton Oilers]] ---- Tim Hrynewich

{{Infobox Athletics Championships |Name= 6th Arab Junior Athletics Championships |Logo = |Size = |Colour = |Optional caption = |Host city = [[Tunis]], Tunisia |Dates = |Stadium = |Nations participating = |Athletes participating = |Events = 42 |Records set = |Previous = [[1992 Arab Junior Athletics Championships|1992 Latakia]] |Next = [[1996 Arab Junior Athletics Championships|1996 Latakia]] }} The '''1994 [[Arab Junior Athletics Championships]]''' was the sixth edition of the international [[athletics (sport)|athletics]] competition for [[Junior athletics|under-20 athletes]] from [[Arab countries]]. It took place in [[Tunis]], Tunisia. Qatar, after a good performance in 1992, did not send a team to the competition. A total of 42 [[athletics events]] were contested, 23 for men and 19 for women.[http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/arj.htm Pan Arab Junior Championships]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2015-02-22. The women's [[10,000 metres]] was restored to the programme after a break in 1992. A women's [[triple jump]] was contested for the first time. The men's 20 km road race made its third and final appearance at the championships, as junior road events were largely dropped from international competitions. The men's hurdles finals were only recorded to the tenth of a second due to technical limitations. Wind affected parts of the competition, particularly the [[200 metres]] races and the horizontal jumps. In line with increased participation, the standard of performers at this event improved. [[Hadi Soua'an Al-Somaily]] won a men's hurdles double for Saudi Arabia and won multiple Asian titles as a senior.[http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/asc.htm Asian Championships]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2015-02-22. [[Ali Hakimi]] defended his [[1500 metres]] title and added the [[800 metres]] crown; he was an Olympic finalist two years later.[https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ha/ali-hakimi-1.html Aki Hakima]. SPorts Reference. Retrieved on 2015-02-22. [[Younès Moudrik]] took the men's long jump title – an event he would win twice at the [[African Championships in Athletics]].[http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/afc.htm African Championships]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2015-02-22. Seventeen-year-old [[Abderrahmane Hammad]] was runner-up in the high jump but later became the first Arab to win a medal in the [[high jump at the Olympics]].[https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/sports/ATH/mens-high-jump.html Athletics Men's High Jump Medalists]. Sports Reference. Retrieved on 2015-02-22. On the women's side, [[Fatma Lanouar]] won the [[800 metres]] in Tunis and was a two-time [[Mediterranean Games]] champion as a senior.[http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/mg.htm Mediterranean Games]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2015-02-22. The runner-up in that event, 16-year-old [[Hasna Benhassi]] of Morocco, had even greater success in her career, which included two Olympic and two World Championships medals.[https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/be/hasna-benhassi-1.html Hasna Benhassi]. Sports Reference. Retrieved on 2015-02-22. Future African champion [[Aïda Sellam]] of Tunisia won the [[javelin throw]] and a [[shot put]] bronze medal on home turf. The winner of the women's walk, [[Nagwa Ibrahim Ali]], would become a prominent athlete in her discipline regionally, with three African titles to her name. ==Medal summary== ===Men=== {| {{MedalistTable|type=Event|columns=2}} |- |100 metres |{{flagathlete|[[Yacine Djellil]]|ALG}} || 10.88 |{{flagathlete|[[Mohammed Masoud Salem]]|KSA}} || 11.10 |{{flagathlete|[[Wisam Bouaïcha]]|TUN}} || 11.13 |- |200 metres

{{Infobox football match | title = 2017 Supercopa MX | image = [[File:2017 Supercopa MX poster.jpg|250px]] | caption = | event = 2017 Supercopa MX | team1 = [[Querétaro F.C.|Querétaro]] | team1association = | team1score = 2 | team2 = [[Club América|América]] | team2association = | team2score = 0 | details = | date = 16 July 2017 | stadium = [[StubHub Center]], [[Carson, California|Carson]] | city = [[Carson, California|California]], [[United States]] | man_of_the_match2a = | man_of_the_match2atitle = | man_of_the_match2b = | man_of_the_match2btitle = | referee2 = Erick Yair Miranda ([[Guanajuato]]) | attendance2 = 13,783 | weather2 = | previous = [[2016 Supercopa MX|2016]] | next = ''[[2018 Supercopa MX|2018]]'' }} The '''2017 [[Supercopa MX]]''' was a [[Football in Mexico|Mexican]] [[Association football|football]] match-up played on 16 July 2017 between the champions of the [[Apertura 2016 Copa MX|Apertura 2016]] [[Copa MX]], [[Querétaro F.C.|Querétaro]], and [[Club América|América]]. Like the previous two editions, the 2017 Supercopa MX was contested in a single-leg format at a neutral venue in the [[Soccer in the United States|United States]]. This match took place at the [[StubHub Center]] in [[Carson, California|Carson]], [[California]] for the second straight year.{{cite web|url=http://www.stubhubcenter.com/news/detail/stubhub-center-selected-to-host-2nd-annual-campeon-de-campeones-and-supercopa-on-july-10th|title=Campeón de Campeones and SuperCopa|accessdate=15 July 2016}} The match is normally contested by the winners of the Apertura and Clausura editions of the [[Copa MX]]. However [[C.D. Guadalajara|Guadalajara]], winners of the [[Clausura 2017 Copa MX|Clausura 2017]], also won the [[2016–17 Liga MX season#Torneo Clausura|Clausura 2017 Liga MX]], and thus qualified for the [[2017 Campeón de Campeones]].http://espndeportes.espn.com/futbol/mexico/nota/_/id/3285642/chivas-y-tigres-disputaran-campeon-de-campeones Since Guadalajara were also the Supercopa MX title holders, they were replaced by [[Club América|América]], who were the team that accumulated the most aggregate points in the previous two editions of Copa MX that was not already playing in either the [[Campeón de Campeones]] or Supercopa MX. The 2017 Supercopa MX was part of a doubleheader, which also includes the [[2017 Campeón de Campeones]], organized by [[Univision Deportes]], [[Soccer United Marketing|Soccer United Marketing (SUM)]], [[Liga MX]] and [[LA Galaxy]]. ==Match details== {{footballbox |date = 16 July 2017 |time = 14:36 ([[UTC−08:00]]) |team1 = [[Querétaro F.C.|Querétaro]] |score = 2–0 |report = http://www.lacopamx.net/cancha/detallenoticia/21128/club-queretaro-es-campeon-de-la-supercopa-mx-2017 |team2 = [[Club América|América]] |goals1 = [[Emanuel Villa|Villa]] {{goal|13|pen.}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} [[File:Athletics track.jpg|thumb|right|Starting lines on an all-weather track]] An '''all-weather running track''' is a rubberized artificial [[Race track|running surface]] for [[track and field athletics]]. It provides a consistent surface for competitors to test their athletic ability unencumbered by adverse weather conditions. Historically, various forms of dirt, grass, sand and crushed [[Cinder track|cinders]] were used. Many examples of these varieties of track still exist worldwide.
==Measurement of a track==
The proper length of the 1st lane of a competitive running track is {{convert|400|m|ft|1|abbr=on}}. Some tracks are not built to this specification, instead some are legacy to [[Imperial units|imperial]] distances like {{convert|440|yd|m|1|abbr=on}}. Prior to rule changes in 1979, distances in [[Imperial units]] were still used in the United States. Some facilities build tracks to fit the available space. One of the most notable examples of this is [[Franklin Field]] where the 400 meter distance is achieved in lane 5. Olympic tracks in the early 20th century were of other lengths. Each lane of the track could (by [[IAAF]] rules should) be as wide as {{convert|122|cm|ft|2|abbr=on}},<ref>{{cite web|title=IAAF Track and Field Facilities Manual 2008 Edition - Chapters 1-3|url=http://www.iaaf.org/download/download?filename=77c027b0-46b8-405d-9ffd-889fa28e3f6e.pdf&urlslug=IAAF%20Track%20and%20Field%20Facilities%20Manual%202008%20Edition%20-%20Chapters%201-3|publisher=IAAF|accessdate=25 August 2013}}</ref> though the majority of American tracks are built to [[National Federation of State High School Associations|NFHS]] high school specifications that allow smaller lanes.<ref>{{cite web|title=2013 NFHS Rule Book - USA Track & Field|url=http://www.usatf.org/groups/officials/files/resources/rules/2013-NFHS-Rule-Book.pdf|publisher=NFHS|accessdate=25 August 2013}}</ref> The IAAF also specifies a preferred radius for the turns at 37 metres, but allows a range. Major international level meets are conducted and world records are allowed to be set on tracks that are not exactly 37 metres, but do fall in the range.
===Lane measurement=== [[File:Piste athlétisme-en.svg|thumb|Track and field stadium layout]]
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Lane !! Total length !! Radius !! Semi-circle length !! Delta !! Angle |- | 1 || 400.00 m || 36.80 m || 115.61 m || 0.00 m || 0.00° |- | 2 || 407.67 m || 38.02 m || 119.44 m || 3.83 m || 5.78° |- | 3 || 415.33 m || 39.24 m || 123.28 m || 7.67 m || 11.19° |- | 4 || 423.00 m || 40.46 m || 127.11 m || 11.50 m || 16.28° |- | 5 || 430.66 m || 41.68 m || 130.94 m || 15.33 m || 21.08° |- | 6 || 438.33 m || 42.90 m || 134.77 m || 19.16 m || 25.60° |- | 7 || 446.00 m || 44.12 m || 138.61 m || 23.00 m || 29.86° |- | 8 || 453.66 m || 45.34 m || 142.44 m || 26.83 m || 33.90° |- | 9 || 461.33 m || 46.56 m || 146.27 m || 30.66 m || 37.73° |}
* Lane - The ordinal number of the lane with the first lane being on the inside * Total length - The total length of the lane * Radius - The radius of the curve 0.30m from the inner side into that lane * Semi-circle length - The length of the half circle of track at that radius * Delta - The length a track of this radius is longer than the inside track (and thus how much lead-in is needed to make it a fair race) * Angle - The corresponding staggering angle (Starting at this offset ensures that a racer in that lane runs the same distance on a curve.)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://datagenetics.com/blog/may12015/index.html|title=Running Track Geometry|website=datagenetics.com|accessdate=1 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livestrong.com/article/168904-what-is-the-distance-around-a-running-track-for-each-lane/|title=What Is the Distance Around a Running Track for Each Lane?|first=Kurt|last=Schuster|publisher=[[LIVESTRONG.COM]] |date= 11 September 2017 |accessdate=1 June 2018}}</ref>
==History==
Starting in the late 1950s, artificial surfaces using a combination of rubber and asphalt began to appear. An artificial warm-up track was constructed for the [[1956 Summer Olympics]] in [[Melbourne]], Australia.{{cn|date=October 2018}} During the 1960s many of these tracks were constructed; examples still exist today.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trackinfo.org/tracks.html |title=California and Nevada All-Weather Tracks |work=Trackinfo.org |date=17 February 1997 |accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref>
In the mid-1960s [[Tartan track]]s, surfaced with a product by [[3M]]. The name ''Tartan'' is a trademark, but many have misused it as a [[genericized trademark]]. This process was the first to commercialize a [[polyurethane]] surface for running tracks, though originally conceived for horse racing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tartan-aps.com/history.php |title=Tartan - History |work=Tartan-aps.com |date= |accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> Many Tartan tracks were installed worldwide, including at many of the top Universities in the United States. Among that list was a Tartan track installed in the [[Estadio Olímpico Universitario]], home of the [[1968 Summer Olympics]] at [[Mexico City]], which were the first global championships to use such a track. [[Athletics at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's shot put|Olympic shot put champion]] [[Bill Nieder]] was instrumental in developing the product and selling it for this first use in the Olympics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://elitetrack.com/blogs-details-2764/ |title=Bill Nieder: Putter Formulated The Rubber Room |publisher=Elitetrack |date= |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> An all-weather surface has become standard ever since.
Another Tartan track was installed on a temporary basis for the 1968 [[United States Olympic Trials (track and field)|United States Olympic Trials]] held at altitude at [[Echo Summit]], [[California]], before being moved to [[South Tahoe Middle School]], where it survived for almost 40 years. An original Tartan track is still in place at "Speed City" [[San Jose State University]] on a satellite to the campus at 10th Street and Alma. Years of the abuse of tractors tearing it and cars parked on it shows the durability of this original product.{{cn|date=October 2018}}
Surfacing tracks has become an industry with many competitors.
* [[Tartan track |Tartan]]; The legacy of the brand is now known as Tartan APS.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tartan-aps.com/|title=Tartan - The ORIGINAL Polyurethane Athletic Surface|website=www.tartan-aps.com|accessdate=1 June 2018}}</ref> * [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] 440;<ref>http://www.baylorbears.com/school-bio/bay-hart-trackfield.html {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101224230447/http://www.baylorbears.com/school-bio/bay-hart-trackfield.html |date=24 December 2010 }} Baylor track history</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gopoly.com/index.php?p%3Dfacilities |title=Archived copy |accessdate=22 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mCRGYa5r?url=http://www.gopoly.com/index.php?p=facilities |archivedate=22 December 2009 |df= }} Cal Poly track history</ref> was a popular surface of the mid-1970s. * Rekortan; was invented and used for the [[1972 Summer Olympics]] in [[Munich]], Germany<ref>http://precisionsurfaces.com/pages/rekortan/ {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719071635/http://precisionsurfaces.com/pages/rekortan/ |date=19 July 2009 }} Rekortan history</ref> and is still licensed worldwide. * Eurotan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.totalsportscy.com/eurotanlogo.html |title=Products Eurotan |work=Totalsportscy.com |date= |accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> * Martin ISS<ref>http://www.beynonsports.com/aboutus/martin_surfacing.aspx {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081119141618/http://www.beynonsports.com/aboutus/martin_surfacing.aspx |date=19 November 2008 }} Martin history</ref> was another 1970's development which now goes by the name of the manufacturer [[Beynon Sports Surfaces|Beynon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beynonsports.com|title=Beynon Sports - Making fast look good|website=www.beynonsports.com|accessdate=1 June 2018}}</ref> * Plexitracs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.plexipave.com |title=Plexipave – A California Sports Surfaces Brand |work=Plexipave.com |date= |accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> * [[Mondotrack]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mondotrackusa.com/Super_X_Performance.cfm?id_applicazione=109&id_tipologia_prodotto=2&id_classe=1&outdoor=1 |title=Mondo Spa |work=Mondotrackusa.com |date= |accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref>
And there are other techniques that distribute small chunks of rubber then adhere them in place with various Polyurethane or [[latex]] substances.
The [[International Association of Athletics Federations]] ([[IAAF]]), international governing body of the sport, publishes very specific regulations for the conduct of a Global Championship or International level track meet (which is their jurisdiction of the sport).<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.iaaf.org/mm/Document/AboutIAAF/Publications/05/26/93/20090923010557_httppostedfile_IAAFTechnicalRegulations31July2009(4)_16740.pdf# |title=Archived copy |access-date=16 December 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023235316/http://www.iaaf.org/mm/Document/AboutIAAF/Publications/05/26/93/20090923010557_httppostedfile_IAAFTechnicalRegulations31July2009(4)_16740.pdf# |archive-date=23 October 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Since the early 1980s, the manufacturer of the surfaces selected for most championship meets has been the [[Italy|Italian]] company, [[Mondo (Italian company)|Mondo]], again the [[trademark]]ed brand name becoming misused as a genericized trademark. Mondo's track surface is called [[Mondotrack]]. The surface differs from the particles stuck in adhesion techniques, in that they are more of a rubber carpet, cut to size then tightly seamed together (in the linear direction along the lane lines). This form of construction gives a more consistent bounce (or energy return) and traction.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-18735617|title=Inside line on 2012 Olympics track|first=Alejandra|last=Martins|date=23 July 2012|accessdate=1 June 2018|work=BBC News}}</ref> Because of the tight fit specifications required for manufacture, construction surrounding these sites also has to be of a higher standard, making a Mondotrack one of the most expensive systems to use. Examples of Mondotracks were used for the [[1996 Summer Olympics]] (since removed from the [[Centennial Olympic Stadium]]) in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], United States; [[2004 Summer Olympics]] in [[Athens]], [[Greece]]; [[2008 Summer Olympics]] in [[Beijing]], China; [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in [[London]], United Kingdom and the [[2016 Summer Olympics]] in [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]].<ref>http://www.mondoworldwide.com/Showreferences.cfm?pagina=1&id_root_ref=3&id_applicazione=15</ref><ref>http://www.iaaf.org/mm/Document/Competitions/TechnicalArea/04/43/20/20091207100318_httppostedfile_Tracks_1Dec09_17528.pdf {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023235321/http://www.iaaf.org/mm/Document/Competitions/TechnicalArea/04/43/20/20091207100318_httppostedfile_Tracks_1Dec09_17528.pdf |date=23 October 2012 }} IAAF Certified Track list</ref>
Another player in the marketplace is [[BASF]]-owned Conica, which can boast the [[2009 World Championships in Athletics]] in [[Berlin]], Germany (where [[Usain Bolt]] improved his [[100 meters]] and [[200 meters]] world records), along with other record hosting venues like [[Stadio Olimpico]] in [[Rome]], Italy <ref>http://www.conica.basf.com/en/news/Pages/World’sBestMeetings2009HostedonCONICATracks.aspx</ref>
==See also==

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Blades of Glory | image = Bladesofglory2007.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = {{Plainlist| * [[Josh Gordon (film director) |Josh Gordon]] * Will Speck }} | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[John Jacobs (producer)|John Jacobs]] * [[Ben Stiller]] * [[Stuart Cornfeld]] }} | screenplay = {{Plainlist| * [[John Altschuler]] * Jeff Cox * Craig Cox * Dave Krinsky * Busy Philipps (uncredited) }} | story = {{Plainlist| * Busy Philipps * Jeff Cox * Craig Cox }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Will Ferrell]] * [[Jon Heder]] * [[Will Arnett]] * [[Amy Poehler]] * [[William Fichtner]] * [[Jenna Fischer]] * [[Craig T. Nelson]] }} | music = [[Theodore Shapiro (composer)|Theodore Shapiro]] | cinematography = [[Stefan Czapsky]] | editing = [[Richard Pearson (film editor)|Richard Pearson]] | studio = {{Plainlist| * [[DreamWorks|DreamWorks Pictures]] * [[MTV Films]] * [[Red Hour Productions|Red Hour]] * Smart Entertainment }} | distributor = [[Paramount Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2007|03|30}} | runtime = 93 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $61 million<ref name="bomj">{{mojo title|bladesofglory}}</ref> | gross = $145.7 million<ref name="bomj"/> }} '''''Blades of Glory''''' is a 2007 American [[comedy film]] directed by [[Josh Gordon (film director)|Josh Gordon]] and Will Speck, written by [[John Altschuler]], Jeff Cox, Craig Cox, and Dave Krinsky, and starring [[Will Ferrell]] and [[Jon Heder]]. The movie was based on an original idea by [[Busy Philipps]] and she "fleshed out the screenplay."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ivie |first1=Devon |title=Busy Philipps Was ‘Gaslit’ Into Thinking She Didn’t Actually Dream Up Blades of Glory |url=https://www.vulture.com/2018/11/busy-philipps-talks-trauma-of-her-blades-of-glory-credit.html |website=New York mag |accessdate=18 November 2018}}</ref> However, Jeff and Craig Cox dropped her name from the script.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kile |first1=Meredith |title=13 of Busy Philipps' Best Celeb Stories From 'This Will Only Hurt a Little' |url=https://www.etonline.com/13-of-busy-philipps-best-celeb-stories-from-this-will-only-hurt-a-little-111604 |website=ET |accessdate=18 November 2018}}</ref> The movie was produced by [[MTV Films]], [[Red Hour Productions|Red Hour]] and Smart Entertainment and released on March 30, 2007, by [[DreamWorks|DreamWorks Pictures]].
==Plot== At the 2002 World Winter Sport Games, rival [[single skating|men's singles skaters]] Chazz Michael Michaels, a skillful skater but raunchy sex addict, and Jimmy MacElroy, an equally talented but sheltered and effeminate skater, tie for gold. While standing on the awards podium, the two have an argument that escalates into a fight and ends with the World Games mascot being accidentally set on fire. As a result, the National Figure Skating Association strips both men of their medals and bans them from men's singles competition for life. Jimmy's competitive adoptive father, billionaire Darren MacElroy, immediately [[Disownment|disowns]] him and leaves him stranded on the side of the road.
Three and a half years later, both men have grudgingly taken on alternative occupations: Jimmy is working at a winter sporting goods store. He gets demoted to stockroom duty when he refuses to listen to a little girl when she tells him her skating boot has been tied too tightly. Chazz plays the role of "The Evil Wizard" in a children's skating show called "Grublets On Ice", until he is fired for ruining the show by being in a drunken stupor on stage.
Jimmy's obsessive stalker, Hector, tells him of a loophole in the ban allowing him to compete in [[pair skating]]. In hopes of entering the upcoming [[2006 Winter Olympics|World Winter Sport Games]], Jimmy contacts his old coach, Robert, but is unable to find a partner. Jimmy's search for a last-minute partner leads him to Chazz, and Robert convinces the two to skate as the first-ever same-sex pairs team, because the regulations fail to state the genders of the pairs.
Robert informs them that to win, they will need to get along and perform an element that has never been performed successfully: The "Iron Lotus", an extremely complicated maneuver that Robert developed years ago. However, it is also dangerous: the only attempt of the maneuver was "behind the [[Bamboo Curtain]]" in [[North Korea]], and resulted in the man [[decapitating]] the woman with his skate blade. Nonetheless, they decide to attempt it as Robert is convinced that two males would be better suited for the move because of the physics of a same-sex team. In the meantime, brother and sister competitors Stranz Van Waldenberg, and Fairchild Van Waldenberg are worried that their spot as the top team is threatened when Jimmy and Chaz perform well at a Winter Sports Games qualifier, command Katie Van Waldenberg, their younger sister, to disrupt the duo by going out with Jimmy and then having sex with Chazz.
Since Katie has fallen in love with Jimmy after going on a date with him, her elder siblings threaten to harm him if she does not comply. Katie gets Chazz's attention after attending a sex addict's meeting as the newest member, then invites Chazz to her room, and tries to seduce him. Chazz refuses out of respect for Jimmy, delighting Katie, but cannot resist grabbing her breasts. Jimmy witnesses this and is outraged at Chazz's and Katie's betrayals. Chazz attempts numerous times to apologize to Jimmy, but is unsuccessful.
In an attempt to sabotage the performance the following day, Stranz and Fairchild kidnap both Chazz and Jimmy, but both are able to escape. Chazz and Jimmy arrive in the ice rink just in time to compete, where they reconcile quickly and begin their routine. Fairchild, seeing the two doing well, throws pearls onto the ice, causing Chazz to trip and break his ankle, rendering him unable to perform his role in the Iron Lotus. Jimmy then offers to switch places with him.
Although they have never practiced the other's roles, they perform it perfectly, winning the competition. Jimmy reconciles with Katie, and Stranz and Fairchild are arrested due to the kidnappings and Stranz accidentally shooting a mascot. Stranz and Fairchild begin arguing, then [[Incest|kiss each other incestuously]] before they are handcuffed by the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]]. Jimmy and Chazz receive the gold medal and fly off into the sky via rockets on their skates. During the credits, Hector is seen playing with dolls of himself, Jimmy and Chazz.
==Cast== * [[Will Ferrell]] as Charles "Chazz" Michael Michaels * [[Jon Heder]] as James "Jimmy" MacElroy ** Zachary Ferren as Young James "Jimmy" MacElroy * [[Will Arnett]] as Stranz Van Waldenberg * [[Amy Poehler]] as Fairchild Van Waldenberg * [[William Fichtner]] as Darren MacElroy * [[Jenna Fischer]] as Katie Van Waldenberg * [[Craig T. Nelson]] as Coach Robert * [[Romany Malco]] as Jesse * [[Nick Swardson]] as Hector * [[Rob Corddry]] as Bryce * [[William Daniels]] as Commissioner Ebbers * [[Luke Wilson]] as Sex Class Counselor
===Skaters as members of cast or crew=== The film's cast and crew includes dozens of people with backgrounds in skating: {{div col}} * [[Sarah Kawahara]] – Main Choreographer * [[Lisa-Marie Allen|Lisa Marie Allen]] – Assistant Choreographer * [[Sasha Cohen]] – Herself * [[Scott Hamilton (figure skater)|Scott Hamilton]] – Himself/Commentator * [[Peggy Fleming]] – Herself/Skating Official * [[Brian Boitano]] – Himself/Skating Official * [[Dorothy Hamill]] – Herself/Skating Official * [[Nancy Kerrigan]] – Herself/Skating Official * Chad Brennan – Will Ferrell's skating double * [[Ethan Burgess]] – Jon Heder's skating double * Patrick Hancock – Will Arnett's skating double / Will Ferrell's skating double 2 * [[Tiffany Scott]] – Amy Poehler's skating double * [[Todd Sand]] – Additional skating/Jon Heder * Forrest Ryan McKinno – Chazz Stunt Skate Double Chase * Scott Irvine – Stunt Skate Double * Armen Saakian – Stunt Skate Double * Akop Manoukian – Stunt Skate Double * [[John Zimmerman (figure skater)|John Zimmerman]] – Stunts/Himself * [[Kyoko Ina]] – Stunts/Herself * [[Yuka Sato]] – Stunts/Herself * [[Jamie Salé]] – Stunts/Herself * [[David Pelletier]] – Stunts/Himself * Benjamin C. Oberman – Skating Consultant * Jonathon DePaz – On-ice Camera Operator * [[Judy Blumberg]] – Amy Poehler's coach * Susan Austin – Will Ferrell's coach * Dawn Porter – Jon Heder's coach * Julie Brault – Skating Coach (Montreal) * [[Matt Evers]] – Skate Tree 1 {{div col end}}
==Production== The movie was based on Busy Philipps' idea and she worked on the screenplay. However, in an oral history about the movie for [[Nerdist]], Craig Cox fully attributed the idea of Blades of Glory to his Jeff Cox. The oral history has since been updated with information about Philipps' contributions. <ref>{{cite web |last1=Ivie |first1=Devon |title=Busy Philipps Was ‘Gaslit’ Into Thinking She Didn’t Actually Dream Up Blades of Glory |url=https://www.vulture.com/2018/11/busy-philipps-talks-trauma-of-her-blades-of-glory-credit.html |website=New York mag |accessdate=18 November 2018}}</ref>
All of the scenes at the National Figure Skating Championships and World Wintersport Games were shot at the [[Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena]]. The stadium used for the outside shoots is the unique [[Olympic Stadium (Montreal)|Montreal Olympic Stadium]], built for the [[1976 Summer Olympics|1976 Olympics]]. The outdoor chase scenes were also shot on-location in [[Montreal]]. The building used for athlete housing in Montreal was the unique [[Habitat 67]], built for [[Expo 67]]. The film was delayed for a small undetermined period of time when [[Jon Heder]] broke his ankle while doing a skating program for the film.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2006/04/07/jon_heder_shoots_blades_of_glory_with_br/ |title=Jon Heder Shoots "Blades of Glory" With Broken Ankle – Starpulse Entertainment News Blog |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060414092453/http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2006/04/07/jon_heder_shoots_blades_of_glory_with_br/ |archivedate=2006-04-14 |df= }}</ref>
==Reception==
===Box office=== ''Blades of Glory'' grossed $118.2 million in the U.S. and Canada and $26.3 million in other territories, for a total of $145.7 million.<ref name="mojo">{{cite web|url= http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=bladesofglory.htm |publisher= Amazon.com |work = [[Box Office Mojo]] |title=Blades of Glory}}</ref>
The film grossed $33 million on its opening weekend on March 30–April 1, 2007, with 3,372 theaters, averaging $9,790 per screen, beating out Disney's ''[[Meet the Robinsons]]'' to be the number 1 film. It made $22.5 million in its second weekend, losing only 32% of its audience and retaining the Number 1 spot.
===Critical response=== {{Anchor|Critics}} The film received positive reviews from critics. Review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gave the film a score of 70%, based on 183 reviews, with an average rating of 6.2/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Thanks to the spirited performances of a talented cast - particularly Will Ferrell and Jon Heder as rivals-turned-teammates -- Blades of Glory successfully spoofs inspirational sports dramas with inspired abandon."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/blades_of_glory/|title=Blades of Glory|author=|date=|website=rottentomatoes.com}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]] the film has a score of 64 out of 100, based on 35 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".
''[[The Monthly]]'' critic [[Luke Davies]] accepted the film as a fun romp, comparing it to Will Ferrell's previous movies ''[[Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy]]'' and ''[[Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby]]'' and wrote positively of Ferrell's performance, describing that "there is a parodic exhilaration to everything Ferrell does; there's always the sense that any scene is precariously close to being a blooper reel." However, Davies conceded that, like the other two films, the plot was "formulaic ... [with] an obviousness to the set-ups, a no-nonsense compression, a sometimes clunky transition from one sequence to the next" but that it was the film's ability to "venture to fantastically absurd places – to set aside the rapid and hokey forward movement – and there to idle in neutral, in zones of pure comic exploration" and offer "moments of expansive hilarity ... that made the films worthwhile."<ref name="The Monthly">{{cite web|url=http://www.themonthly.com.au/film-luke-davies-mind-bottling-will-speck-amp-josh-gordon-s-039blades-glory039-567?page=0%2C1|publisher= ''[[The Monthly]]''|title="Mind Bottling: Will Speck & Josh Gordon's "Blades of Glory"}}</ref>
==Home video== The film was released on [[DVD]] and [[HD DVD]] on August 7, 2007, and released on [[Blu-ray Disc]] on May 20, 2008.
==References== ;Citations {{Reflist}} ;General references {{Refbegin}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2007-02-04-blades-of-glory_x.htm |title=Heder, Ferrell skate for comedy gold |accessdate=February 5, 2007 |last=Breznican |first=Anthony |date=February 5, 2007 |publisher=USA Today}} * {{cite web |url=http://news.bostonherald.com/localRegional/view.bg?articleid=187755 |title=Leap into Hollywood: Local skater subs for Will Ferrell in comedy "Blades of Glory" |accessdate=March 11, 2007 |last=Tolson |first=Shaun |date=March 11, 2007 |publisher=Boston Herald |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070323010820/http://news.bostonherald.com/localRegional/view.bg?articleid=187755 |archivedate=March 23, 2007 |df= }} {{Refend}}
==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{Allmovie title|341075}} * {{IMDb title|0445934}} * {{metacritic film|blades-of-glory}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|blades_of_glory}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.lakeshore-records.com/bladesofglory/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105211149/http://www.lakeshore-records.com/bladesofglory/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2009-01-05|title=Blades of Glory Soundtrack|work=Lakeshore Records}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Burnham Pavilion | former_names = Stanford Pavilion
Old Pavilion | nickname = | image = | location = 615 Serra Street,
[[Stanford, California|Stanford]], [[California]] | coordinates = {{coord|37.4285|-122.1643 |format=dms |type:landmark_region:US-CA |display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = January 24, 1922 | renovated = 1989 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | tenants = [[Stanford Cardinal]] | seating_capacity = 1,436 | dimensions = }}'''Burnham Pavilion''' is a multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Stanford, California]]. It was built in 1921 and 1922 at a cost of $153,000 by [[Arthur Brown, Jr.|Bakewell and Brown]]{{cite book|title=Stanford University|last=Joncas|first=Richard |author2=David J. Neuman |author3=Paul Venable Turner |location=New York|publisher=Princeton Architectural Press|year=2006}} and originally named the "Stanford Pavilion".{{cite web | url= http://www.gostanford.com/ViewArticle.dbml?&DB_OEM_ID=30600&ATCLID=208446884 | title= Burnham Pavilion & Ford Center |date= |year= |month= | publisher= [[Stanford Cardinal|Stanford University Athletics]] | accessdate= June 5, 2014 }} It was home to the [[Stanford University]] Cardinal [[basketball]] team prior to [[Maples Pavilion]] opening in 1968. When it opened, it was the largest arena used exclusively for basketball. On March 10, 1953, the Pavilion hosted a first round [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]] matchup between the [[University of Santa Clara]] and [[Hardin-Simmons University]].http://www.databasesports.com/ncaab/tourney.htm?yr=1953 It was known for many years as the "Old Pavilion" but was renamed ''Burnham Pavilion'' in 1989 after [[Malin Burnham]], a principal contributor to a renovation that increased capacity to 1,400.{{cite web|url=http://www.gostanford.com/fls/30600/old_site/pdf/m-wrestl/0910-mg-section1.pdf?DB_OEM_ID=30600|title=Stanford Wrestling Media Guide|accessdate=June 5, 2014|page=8|publisher=Stanford University|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606211620/http://www.gostanford.com/fls/30600/old_site/pdf/m-wrestl/0910-mg-section1.pdf?DB_OEM_ID=30600|archivedate=June 6, 2014|df=}} As of 2009 it houses the gymnastics teams, the [[Collegiate wrestling|wrestling]] team and the men's volleyball team. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/stan/sports/m-baskbl/auto_pdf/0607-mg-05.pdf Arena information] {{Stanford University}} {{Stanford Cardinal men's basketball navbox}} [[Category:Stanford Cardinal basketball]] [[Category:Defunct college basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Basketball venues in California]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in California]] [[Category:Sports venues in the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Stanford University buildings and structures]] [[Category:Arthur Brown Jr. buildings]] [[Category:Sports venues in Santa Clara County, California]] [[Category:1922 establishments in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1922]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in California]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College wrestling venues in the United States]] [[Category:Wrestling venues in California]] {{California-sports-venue-stub}} {{SantaClaraCountyCA-struct-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | name = Campo Argentino de Polo | nickname = ''Cathedral of Polo'' | native_name = Argentine Polo Ground | native_name_lang = | fullname = Campo Argentino de Polo | former names = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Campo Polo.jpg | image_size = 250px | image_alt = | caption = The Campo Argentino during
a polo match in 2014 | pushpin_map = | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = | address = [[Avenida del Libertador]] and Avenida Dorrego | location = [[Palermo, Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] | coordinates = | type = Stadium | genre = Sport events
Music concerts | broke_ground = | built = | opened = {{Start date and years ago|1928|10|27}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Argentine Army]] | operator = Argentine Polo Association [http://www.espn.com.ar/otros-deportes/polo/nota/_/id/2797645/el-campo-argentino-de-polo-esta-en-peligro ¿El Campo Argentino de Polo está en peligro?], ESPN, 22 Sep 2016 | surface = [[Poaceae#Sports_turf|Grass]] | scoreboard = | production = | cost = | architect = | builder = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = 30,000 [http://www.argentina.travel/es/puntos-de-interes/campo-argentino-de-polo/442#.WiqHmdLibIU Campo Argentino de Polo] on Argentina.Travel | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = | embedded = | website = | publictransit = }} The '''Campo Argentino del Polo''' ('''Argentine Polo Ground'''), popularly known as ''The Cathedral of Polo'', is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]]. It is currently used mostly for [[polo]], [[pato]] and [[field hockey]] matches.[https://turismo.buenosaires.gob.ar/es/atractivo/campo-argentino-de-polo Campo Argentino de Polo] on GCBA Turismo The stadium, opened in 1928, holds up to 30,000 people and is located in the [[Palermo, Buenos Aires|Palermo]] [[Neighbourhoods of Buenos Aires|neighbourhood]], on [[Avenida del Libertador|Del Libertador Avenue]], close to [[Hipódromo Argentino de Palermo|Hipódromo Argentino]].[http://www.argentinatravelplanet.com/sports-in-argentina/polo-in-argentina/ Polo in Argentina] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726131734/http://www.argentinatravelplanet.com/sports-in-argentina/polo-in-argentina/# |date=2011-07-26 }} Argentina Travel This is a unique polo field, situated ten minutes away from downtown Buenos Aires, and is considered the most complete, modern and comfortable for spectators in the sport.. The Campo Argentino, is the home to the [[Campeonato Argentino Abierto de Polo]], the most important polo event in the world, held there since 1928. It is organized by the [[Asociación Argentina de Polo]]. ==History== [[File:Campo argentino polo 1940.jpg|thumb|left|The Campo Argentino in 1940]] The Campo Argentino was erected on the same land where the [[Sociedad Sportiva Argentina]] stadium had been located since its establishment in 1899 until its expropriation from the [[Government of Argentina]] in 1914, when the [[Argentine Army|National Army]] took over the stadium after the second period of five years (counting from 1909) came to an end. Ten years later, the Ministry of War led by [[Agustín P. Justo]] expropriated the lands and transferred them to the Army, which is its owner since then.[http://historiapolitica.com/datos/biblioteca/daskal2.pdf La Sociedad Sportiva Argentina y su terreno, historia de una disputa] by Rodrigo Daskal on Historia Política After taking the lands, the Army built two polo fields (known as "canchas 1 y 2"). The Campo Argentino was officially inaugurated on October 27, 1928, with a match between civil and military teams (named "Civiles" and "Militares" respectively).[http://www.infocampo.com.ar/el-campo-argentino-de-polo-del-barrio-de-palermo-estara-abierto-para-el-turismo/ El Campo Argentino de Polo de Palermo estará abierto para el turismo], Infocampo, 20 Feb 2017 The Army has rented Campo Argentino to the Argentine Polo Association since then. In [[1978 Men's Hockey World Cup|1978]], the Campo Argentino was the venue for all the matches of the [[World Hockey Cup|World Field Hockey Cup]], won by [[Pakistan men's national field hockey team|Pakistan]].[http://www.elmensajerodiario.com.ar/contenidos/hockey-mundial-78_10810/ Hockey: el “otro” Mundial del 78] on El Mensajero, 8 Jul 2011 A total of seven hockey fields were specially prepared on the ''canchas'' 1 and 2 for the occasion.[https://historiasdeportivas.wordpress.com/2009/07/09/argentina-78-los-mundiales-olvidados/ Argentina 78: los mundiales olvidados] Defunct competition [[America's Polo Cup]] ("Copa de las Américas") took place in Campo Argentino on numerous occasions. In this classic match, the best team from Argentina played against the best one from the [[United States]]. The stadium has been also used for music concerts. [[Oasis (band)|Oasis]], [[Jamiroquai]], [[Carlos Santana]], [[Shakira]], [[Neil Young]], [[R.E.M.]], [[Beck]], [[Luciano Pavarotti]], [[The Pretenders]] and [[Phil Collins]] are some of the artists who have performed at Campo Argentino. ==See also== *[[Sociedad Sportiva Argentina]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Buenos Aires}} *[http://www.aapolo.com/ Argentine Polo Association] {{coord|34|34|17.35|S|58|25|37.09|W|type:landmark_region:AR|display=title}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[Hockey World Cup|Men's Hockey World Cup]]
Final Venue| before= [[Kuala Lumpur]] | after=[[Mumbai]]| years='''[[1978 Men's Hockey World Cup|1978]]''' }} {{succession box | title=[[World Polo Championship]]
Venue| before= None | after=[[Olympiastadion (Berlin)|Mailfeld]]
[[Berlin]]| years='''[[1987 World Polo Championship|1987]]''' }} {{s-end}} {{Commons cat|Campo Argentino de Polo}} {{Buenos Aires landmarks}} [[Category:Field hockey venues]] [[Category:Polo in Argentina]] [[Category:Sports venues in Buenos Aires]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Argentina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1928]]

{{Unreferenced|date=February 2007}} {{Infobox football tournament | name = Coupe du Togo | logo = | country = {{TOG}} | founded = 1955 | number of teams = | current champions = | most successful club = | website = | current = [[2018 Coupe du Togo]] }} The '''Coupe du Togo''' is the top knockout tournament of the [[Togo]]lese [[football (soccer)|football]].
==Winners== ===before independence=== *1955 : '''Essor''' (Lomé) *1956 : '''[[Etoile Filante de Lomé]]''' *1958 : '''[[Etoile Filante de Lomé]]'''
===since independence=== *1961 : '''[[Etoile Filante de Lomé]]''' ''unknown winners between 1962 and 1973'' *1974 : '''Omnisports''' (Atakpamé) *1975 : '''[[ASKO Kara]]''' (Kara) *1976 : '''[[ASKO Kara]]''' (Kara) *1977 : '''Edan''' (Lomé) *1978 : ''No Cup'' *1979 : '''[[OC Agaza]]''' (Lomé) *1980 : '''[[AC Semassi F.C.]]''' (Sokodé) *1981 : '''[[OC Agaza]]''' (Lomé) 1-0 [[Us Masseda (football club)|Aiglons]] (Lomé) *1982 : '''[[AC Semassi F.C.]]''' (Sokodé) 1-0 [[OC Agaza]] (Lomé) *1983 : ''No Cup'' *1984 : '''[[OC Agaza]]''' (Lomé) 0-0 (3 t.a.b. à 0) [[ASFOSA]] (Lomé) *1985 : '''[[Foadan F.C.|Foadan FC]]''' (Dapaong) 1-0 Doumbé FC (Sansanné-Mango) *1986 : '''Entente 2''' (Lomé) 2-0 [[ASKO Kara]] (Kara) *1987 : '''[[ASKO Kara]]''' (Kara) 2-1 [[AC Semassi FC]] (Sokodé) *1988 : '''[[OC Agaza]]''' (Lomé) 1-0 [[Ifodje Atakpamé]] (Atakpamé) *1989 : '''Entente 2''' (Lomé) 1-0 [[Us Masseda (football club)|Aiglons]] (Lomé) *1990 : '''[[AC Semassi F.C.]]''' (Sokodé) 2-1 Entente 2 (Lomé) ''No cup between 1991 and 1993'' *1994 : '''[[Etoile Filante de Lomé]]''' 3-2 [[OC Agaza]] (Lomé) *1995 : '''[[ASKO Kara]]''' (Kara) 1-0 [[AC Semassi FC]] (Sokodé) *1996 : '''[[Doumbé F.C.]]''' (Sansanné-Mango) 2-1 [[Etoile Filante de Lomé]] ''No cup between 1997 and 1998'' *1999 : '''[[OC Agaza]]''' (Lomé) 1-0 Entente 2 (Lomé) *2000 : ''unknown winner'' *2001 : '''[[Dynamic Togolais]]''' (Lomé) 3-0 [[Sara Sport de Bafilo|Sara]] (Bafilo) *2002 : '''[[Dynamic Togolais]]''' (Lomé) 2-0 Doumbé FC (Sansanné-Mango) *2003 : '''[[Maranatha F.C.]]''' (Fiokpo) *2004 : '''[[AS Douane]]''' (Lomé) 2-1 [[Foadan F.C.|Foadan FC]] (Dapaong) *2005 : '''[[Dynamic Togolais]]''' (Lomé) 1-0 [[OC Agaza]] (Lomé) *2006 : '''[[AS Togo-Port]]''' (Lomé) 1-1 (5 t.a.b à 4) [[ASKO Kara]]
;Coupe de l'Indépendance *2016 : '''[[US Koroki]]''' (Tchamba) 1-1 [[AS Togo-Port]] (Lomé) [5-3 pen] *2017 : '''[[AS Togo-Port]]''' (Lomé) 3-0 [[Maranatha F.C.]] (Fiokpo)
;Coupe Nationale *[[2018 Coupe du Togo|2018]] : '''[[Gomido FC]]''' (Kpalimé) 3-0 [[Dynamic Togolais]] (Lomé)
==External links== *[http://www.rsssf.com/tablest/togocuphist.html Togo - List of Cup Winners], RSSSF.com

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Descente Ltd. | native_name = 株式会社デサント | native_name_lang = jp | logo = Descente company logo.svg | logo_size = 200px | type = [[public company|Public]] [[Kabushiki kaisha|KK]] | traded_as = {{TYO|8114}} | ISIN = JP3548800006 | founded = ({{Start date and age|1935|02}}) | founder = Takeo Ishimoto | hq_location_city = Dogashiba, [[Tennōji-ku, Osaka|Tennoji-ku]], [[Osaka]], 543-8921 | hq_location_country = Japan | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Masatoshi Ishimoto
([[President (corporate title)|President]]) | industry = [[Textile industry|Apparel]] | products = {{unbulleted list|[[Sportswear (activewear)|Sportswear]]|Sport accessories}} | revenue = {{increase}} [[Japanese yen|JPY]] 123.1 billion ([[Fiscal year|FY]] 2014) ([[US dollar|US$]] 1.1 billion) (FY 2014) | net_income = {{increase}} JPY 6.5 billion (FY 2014) (US$ 59 million) (FY 2014) | num_employees = 1,839 (as of March 31, 2015) | footnotes = {{cite web |url=http://www.descente.co.jp/company/en/profile/ |title=Profile |publisher=Descente |accessdate=February 29, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://asia.nikkei.com/Company/05J3S5-E |title=Company Profile |work=[[Nikkei Asian Review]] |publisher=[[Nikkei Inc.]] |accessdate=February 29, 2016}}{{cite book |title=ASIA Major Wholesalers & Retailers |year=2011 |publisher=Business Information Agency |isbn=978-1-4187-8514-7 |page=83}} | website = {{Official website|http://www.descente.co.jp/company/en/}} }} {{nihongo|'''Descente Ltd.'''|株式会社デサント|Kabushiki-gaisha Desanto}} is a [[Japan]]ese [[sports clothing]] and [[Fashion accessory|accessories]] company,{{cite web|url=http://www.fashionbiz.co.kr/BR/?cate=2&idx=122122|title=데상트코리아 풀 스토리|publisher=Fashionbiz|date=April 11, 2011|accessdate=September 30, 2015|first=Jeong-min|last=Lee}} first formed in 1935, when Takeo Ishimoto started the company in Osaka as Ishimoto Shoten. The company logo depicts 3 basic skiing techniques - [[Traverse (climbing)|traverse]], [[schuss]] and side-slip.{{cite web |url=http://www.snowkings.co.uk/gear/clothing/brands/descente/descente-ski-wear.htm |title=Ski Wear by Descente |work=Snow Kings |accessdate=February 29, 2016}} Descente owns a portfolio of 16 in-house, purchased and licensed brands, among them Descente, Shiseist, [[Arena (swimwear)|Arena]] (in primarily Japan and the Far East), [[Marmot (company)|Marmot]] and [[Srixon]].{{cite web |url=http://www.outdoorsmagic.com/gear-news/descente-acquires-majority-share-in-inov-8/14549.html |title=Descente Acquires Majority Share In inov-8 |first=Jon |last=Doran|work=OutdoorsMagic.com |publisher=[[Immediate Media Company]] |date=August 6, 2015 |accessdate=February 29, 2016}} == History == The forerunner of the company, a men's retail store called Ishimoto Shoten, was founded in 1935. It started developing skiwear in 1954, and registered the Descente trademark in 1961. The "Demopants" ski pants style was launched in 1974, followed in 1979 by the "Magic Suit".{{cite book |first=Roshan |last=Shishoo |title=Textiles in Sport |date=August 29, 2005 |publisher=[[Elsevier]] |isbn=978-1-84569-088-5 |page=52}} A wearable heating system called the "Mobile Thermo" jacket was introduced in 1998. In 2002 the company collaborated with [[Academy Award for Best Costume Design#1990s|Academy Award-winner]] art director and costume designer [[Eiko Ishioka]] in creating the Vortex suits and uniforms, used by the Japanese, Swiss, Spanish and Canadian teams competing in the [[2002 Winter Olympics]].{{cite book |first=Andrew |last=Jaffe |title=Casting for Big Ideas: A New Manifesto for Agency Managers |date=September 24, 2003 |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]] |isbn=978-0-471-48091-4 |page=196}}{{cite news |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/3079010/ns/technology_and_science/t/high-tech-race-olympic-gold/#.Vu8hJnpvW4A |first=Alan |last=Boyle |title=The high-tech race for Olympic gold |date=February 1, 2002 |accessdate=March 21, 2016 |work=[[NBCNews.com]] |publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]}} Other developments since 2000 have included the Mizusawa Down range, the E-liner under-suit for ski and speed skating use, the ACXEL range of support bands and in 2012, Genome high performance compression wear.[[File:Women's downhill, 2014 WOG cropped.jpg|thumb|[[Dominique Gisin]] and [[Lara Gut]] wearing Descente ski suits at the [[2014 Winter Olympics]]]] The company won an ISPO Gold Medal for its ALLTERRAIN Transform Jacket in 2013.{{cite web |url=http://award.ispo.com/en/Winner-2013/Products/Performance/ |title=Product of the year - 2013 |work=ISPO |publisher=[[Messe München]] |accessdate=March 10, 2016}} ==Sponsorships== ===Speed-skating=== The company sponsored the United States speed-skating team in the 1970s and 1980s, including [[Eric Heiden]], who won five gold medals at the [[Speed skating at the 1980 Winter Olympics#Men.27s events|1980 Winter Olympics]] wearing the gold Descente racing suit.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/02/sports/eric-heiden-a-year-later-his-privacy-is-golden.html |title=Eric Heiden a year later: his privacy is golden |first=Frank |last=Litsky |date=February 2, 1981 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=March 17, 2016}}[[File:Eric Heiden 1980c.jpg|thumb|Eric Heiden wearing a Descente racing suit at the [[World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Men|1980 World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Men]]]] It was also a supplier to the Canadian speed-skating team.{{cite news |url=http://velonews.competitor.com/2005/11/news/press-release-descente-named-official-cycling-apparel-of-team-csc_9148 |title=Descente named Official Cycling Apparel of Team CSC |date=November 10, 2005 |work=[[Competitor Group, Inc.#Cycling|VeloNews]] |publisher=Competitor Group, Inc. |accessdate=March 18, 2016}} ===Skiing=== The [[United States Ski Team]], during the 1980s, and later the Swiss alpine ski team was equipped with the company's [[Ski suit|skiwear]].{{cite book |title=[[Skiing (magazine)|Skiing magazine]] |publisher=[[Bonnier Corporation]] |date=September 1983 |page=142 |issn=0037-6264}}{{cite news |url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/swisscom-to-sponsor-skiers/2805142 |title=Swisscom to sponsor skiers |date=July 5, 2002 |work=[[Swissinfo]] |publisher=[[Swiss Broadcasting Corporation]] |accessdate=March 18, 2016}} ===Cycling=== Descente has equipped the [[7-Eleven (cycling team)|7-Eleven Cycling Team]] and [[Tinkoff#Team CSC: 2003.E2.80.932008|Team CSC]], two [[UCI World Tour]] competing teams. ===Baseball=== The company is the official apparel and uniform sponsor of the [[South Korea national baseball team]] having previously supplied South Korea’s under-18 team.{{cite news |url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/news/descente_to_supply_south_korea_at_inaugural_premier12 |title=Descente to supply South Korea at inaugural Premier12 |first=Michael |last=Long |date=September 23, 2015 |work=[[SportsPro]] |publisher=SportsPro Media Ltd. |accessdate=March 18, 2016}} [[File:Baseball TeamKorea IncheonAsianGames 08.jpg|thumb|South Korea baseball team at a press conference before the [[2014 Asian Games]] in Descente uniforms]] ===Motorcycle racing=== In February 2015, [[Yamaha Motor Racing]], a [[Grand Prix motorcycle racing|MotoGP World Championship]] team, signed an Official Sponsorship and Official Supplier agreement with Descente.{{cite news |url=http://rtrsports.co.uk/sports-marketing-yamaha-motor-and-descente-sign-official-sponsor-agreement/ |title=Sports Marketing: Yamaha Motor and Descente sign Official Sponsor Agreement |first=Emanuele |last=Venturoli |date=February 6, 2015 |work=[[RTR Sports]] |publisher=RTR Sports Marketing Ltd. |accessdate=March 18, 2016}} ===Triathlon=== In April 2017 Descente became the Sports Apparel Sponsor to [[British Triathlon Federation|British Triathlon]], supplying the Great Britain Elite and Age-Group Teams with competition, training and travel wear.{{Cite web|url=https://www.britishtriathlon.org/news/descente-has-become-an-official-sponsor-of-british-triathlon_7060|title=DESCENTE has become an Official Sponsor of British Triathlon|website=www.britishtriathlon.org|language=en|access-date=2017-05-12}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Japan|Fashion|Companies}} *{{Official website|http://www.descente.co.jp/}} {{ja}} *[http://www.descentekorea.co.kr/ Descente Korea] {{ko}} *[http://www.descente.com Descente North America] *[http://www.descente.com/uk/ Descente United Kingdom] {{Competitive swimwear}} [[Category:Itochu]] [[Category:Clothing companies of Japan]] [[Category:Sporting goods manufacturers of Japan]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Companies based in Osaka Prefecture]] [[Category:1935 establishments in Japan]] [[Category:Clothing companies established in 1935]] [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:Japanese brands]] [[Category:Swimwear manufacturers]]

{{Infobox darts player | name = Dylan Duo | image = | fullname = | nickname = The Rock | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1977|11|24|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Gibraltar]], Gibraltar | death_date = | death_place = | hometown = Gibraltar | homecountry = Gibraltar | since = 1995 | darts = 22 Gram Bull's | laterality = Right-handed | music = "[[We Will Rock You]]" by [[Queen (band)|Queen]] | BDO = 2003-2008 | PDC = 2008– | currentrank = 194 | BDO World = | World Masters = Last 128: 2005, 2006, 2017 | World Darts Trophy = | Int. Darts League = | PDC World = Last 64: 2010 | Matchplay = | Grand Prix = | UK Open = Last 64: 2010 | Vegas = | Premier League = | results = {{aligned table|leftright=y|fullwidth=y|class=nowrap | '''GDA College Cosmos Open'''| 2012 | '''GDA Dave Obee Singles'''| 2010 | '''GDA Diamond Jubilee Superstars'''| 2012 | '''GDA Invitation Trophy'''| 2012 | '''GDA Joe Goldwin Classic'''| 2010 | '''GDA John Smiths Singles'''| 2010 | '''GDA Johnny Neale Charity Singles'''| 2011, 2012 | '''GDA Masters Singles'''| 2010 | '''GDA Millenium Singles'''| 2009 | '''GDA Willie Duo Singles'''| 2012 | '''Gibraltar National Championships'''| 2008, 2012 | '''Torremolinos Open'''| 2008 }} }}
'''Dylan Duo''' (born 24 November 1977) is a [[Gibraltarian people|Gibraltarian]] [[darts]] player.
==Career==
Duo qualified for the [[2010 PDC World Darts Championship]] via the European Order of Merit. He became the first darts player from [[Gibraltar]] to qualify for either version of the [[World Professional Darts Championship|World Darts Championship]]. In the first round, he was whitewashed 3–0 by [[Vincent van der Voort]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dartsdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=1155 | title=2010 PDC World Championship Results | publisher=Darts Database | accessdate=28 October 2013}}</ref>
He currently plays for and Captains the College Cosmos team in the Gibraltar Darts Association league. In the 2009/10 season he achieved a first by winning all four major domestic ranking tournaments, as well as numerous other tournaments. He served several years as Treasurer of the Gibraltar Darts Association.
Duo represented Gibraltar with [[Dyson Parody]] in the [[2012 PDC World Cup of Darts]] and together they were beaten 5–4 by Denmark in the first round, with Duo missing two darts for the match.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pdc.tv/page/PDCWorldCupArticle/0,,10180~2598931,00.html |title=Cash Converters World Cup RD1 |publisher=[[Professional Darts Corporation|PDC]] |date=3 February 2012 |accessdate=3 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206031856/http://www.pdc.tv/page/PDCWorldCupArticle/0%2C%2C10180~2598931%2C00.html |archivedate=6 February 2012 |df= }}</ref> During the rest of 2012 he won six tournaments on the Gibraltar Darts Association tour.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dylan Duo 2012|url=http://www.dartsdatabase.co.uk/PlayerDetails.aspx?playerKey=3047|work=Darts Database|accessdate=2 February 2013}}</ref>
In January 2013, Duo entered Q School in an attempt to win a two-year PDC Tour Card and was one match away from doing so on the fourth and final day, but lost to [[Steve Coote]] 6–0.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pdc.tv/news/article/1kb9fnz50anlu1b7fwl98sb868/title/pdc-qualifying-school-day-four | title=PDC Qualifying School Day Four | publisher=[[Professional Darts Corporation|PDC]] | accessdate=2 February 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130125042212/http://www.pdc.tv/news/article/1kb9fnz50anlu1b7fwl98sb868/title/pdc-qualifying-school-day-four | archivedate=25 January 2013 | df= }}</ref> Duo played in his third [[2013 PDC World Cup of Darts|World Cup of Darts]] with Dyson Parody in February, but they finished bottom of Group E after losing 5–2 to Poland and 5–0 to the Netherlands.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pdc.tv/news/article/7z70zfb6nkue17rlmi5j1xbbb/title/betfair-world-cup-of-darts---saturday-afternoon | title=Betfair World Cup of Darts - Saturday Afternoon | publisher=[[Professional Darts Corporation|PDC]] | accessdate=February 2, 2013}}</ref> In June he qualified for the [[2013 PDC European Tour Event 5|Gibraltar Darts Trophy]] but was thrashed 6–0 by [[Gary Anderson (darts player)|Gary Anderson]] in the first round.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pdc.tv/news/article/197h5wcior6nyz4aubtymhzlt/title/gibraltar-darts-trophy-day-one | title=Gibraltar Darts Trophy Day One | publisher=[[Professional Darts Corporation|PDC]] | accessdate=28 October 2013}}</ref> In the final of the Iberian qualifier for the [[2014 PDC World Darts Championship|2014 World Championship]], Duo was narrowly beaten 10–9 by [[Julio Barbero]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dartsdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=4484 | title=2013 PDC World Iberian Qualifying Event Results | publisher=Darts Database | accessdate=27 December 2013}}</ref>
At the [[2014 PDC World Cup of Darts|2014 World Cup of Darts]], Duo and Parody were beaten 5–2 by Sweden in the opening round.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pdc.tv/news/article/13ot1jnntsvt21nv34y1z7tv3u/title/bwin-world-cup-of-darts-first-round | title=bwin World Cup of Darts First Round | publisher=[[Professional Darts Corporation|PDC]] | accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref>
In August 2015, Dylan Duo was disciplined by the Darts Regulation Authority for "Threatening behaviour and failure to mark" at the Gibraltar Qualifier for the PDC World Cup. He was fined £350.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thedra.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/DRA-Hearing-results-2015-111.pdf | title=2015 Disciplinary Cases | publisher=Darts Regulation Authority | accessdate=17 December 2015}}</ref>
At the [[2017 PDC World Cup of Darts|2017 World Cup]], Duo and Parody lost 5–2 to England in the opening round.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dartsdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=11145| title=2017 PDC World Cup of Darts Results| publisher=Darts Database| accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref>
==World Championship results==
===PDC===
*2010: First round (lost to [[Vincent van der Voort]] 0–3)
